title-group.article-title: Prescription opioid use and substance use disorder in US women (2006–2022): a retrospective cohort study

contrib-group.aff: aCenter for Surgery and Public Health, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, 75 Francis Street, Boston, MA, 02115, USA
bDepartment of Orthopaedic Surgery, Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, 75 Francis Street, Boston, MA, 02115, USA
cHarvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St, Boston, MA, 02115, USA
dDepartment of Internal Medicine, Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, 75 Francis Street, Boston, MA, 02115, USA
eCenter for Health Services Research, Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, 4301 Jones Bridge Road, Bethesda, MD, 20814, USA

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Research has shown that multiple deployments may have adverse effects on active-duty servicewomen and women civilian dependents of active-duty servicemembers. There is concern that the associated stress could induce sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder (SUD). We sought to evaluate the incidence of sustained opioid use and SUD among servicewomen and women civilian dependents during 2006–2013, a period of increased operational intensity, compared to similar individuals in 2014–2022.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We employed Military Health System claims data to identify servicewomen and dependents who were diagnosed with SUD or demonstrated sustained prescription opioid use (i.e., six months of uninterrupted use). The incidence of sustained opioid use (primary outcome) and SUD associated (secondary outcome) with 2006–2013 was compared to 2014–2022 among servicewomen and dependents. Multivariable log binomial regression was used to adjust for confounding. Ethnicity was not available in our dataset.

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: 4,876,209 individuals were included. The average age (standard deviation [SD]) of the cohorts under study were 26.6 (SD 8.2) for active duty 2006–2013, 26.0 (SD 8.0) for active duty 2014–2022, 35.3 (SD 13.1) for dependents 2006–2013 and 33.6 (SD 12.1) for dependents 2014–2022. Compared to civilian dependents in 2014–2022, servicewomen from 2006 to 2013 demonstrated an increased risk of sustained prescription opioid use (RR 1.49, 95% CI 1.46–1.53). In 2014–2022, servicewomen had a lower risk compared to dependents (RR 0.47, 95% CI 0.45–0.49), while dependents in 2006–2013 were also at higher risk (RR 1.58, 95% CI 1.56–1.60). Servicewomen in 2006–2013 were at significantly greater risk of developing SUD (RR 1.07, 95% CI 1.06–1.08). During 2014–2022, servicewomen displayed a lower risk when compared to dependents (RR 0.80, 95% CI 0.79–0.81). Dependents in 2006–2013 showed a higher risk (RR 1.24, 95% CI 1.24–1.25).

sec.title: Interpretation
sec.p: We found significant increases in the risks of sustained opioid use and SUD among servicewomen and civilian dependents during a period of increased operational intensity (2006–2013). We believe these findings reflect the deleterious effects of emotional stress, insufficient support structures, and military sexual trauma.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: 10.13039/100005712U.S. Department of Defense, Defense Health Agency (#HU00012320021).

sec.title: Evidence before this study
sec.p: We searched PubMed and Scopus for longitudinal studies reporting on the incidence of sustained prescription opioid use, or substance use disorder, among women in the US associated with combat deployment. We employed the following search terms (“addiction, opiate”) AND (“women”) AND (“combat”). The search considered all articles published up to January 22, 2025. The search identified fourteen studies, none of which specifically evaluated the association between time period, operational intensity, and combat deployment on the outcome of interest. An expanded search was performed that included ((addiction, opiate) AND (women [MeSH Terms])) AND (disorder, substance use [MeSH Terms]). This search yielded 114 results, none of which specifically focused on the intent of our investigation either. Most of the work we encountered focused on pregnant women and opioid use disorder, healthcare disparities in the receipt of treatment for opioid addiction among women or pregnant women, and drug-related infections among pregnant women. At present, the question remains as to the association between increased emotional stress associated with deployment frequency and operational intensity of combat deployments and sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder among both active-duty servicewomen and civilian women dependents.

sec.title: Added value of this study
sec.p: This investigation represents one of the largest and most comprehensive longitudinal assessments evaluating the association between operational intensity, combat deployments and the incidence of sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder in both active-duty servicewomen and women civilian dependents. We found significant increases in the risks of sustained prescription opioid use and substance use among active-duty servicewomen and women civilian dependents during the period of increased operational intensity. We believe these findings reflect the deleterious effects of emotional stress, insufficient support structures, and military sexual trauma.

sec.title: Implications of all the available evidence
sec.p: We believe that our findings are translatable to the civilian sector, given that the covered population of the military health system has previously been shown to be analogous to the US demographic aged 18–64. In particular, clinicians in the Veterans Administration system and civilian sector should be aware of a heightened risk of sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder for women veterans who served in Iraq and/or Afghanistan over the time period 2006–2013, as well for women spouses and children of individuals with this type of service history.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the first two decades of the 21st century, while the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts were occurring overseas, the opioid crisis emerged as an existential challenge to the US healthcare system. The conditions of modern warfare, characterized by an increased use of explosive devices with devastating destructive potential and repeated exposure to physical and psychological stressors, have been heralded as risk factors for substance abuse and opioid dependence.1,2

Recent research also claimed that the period of heightened operational intensity associated with troop deployments in Iraq and Afghanistan (2006–2013), culminated in elevated risks of chronic pain conditions in both active-duty servicewomen and civilian women dependents of servicemembers.3 The development of such conditions may increase the potential for sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder (SUD). In the time period of 2006–2013, there was widespread use of opioid medications as the primary means of pain control within the military healthcare setting.4 Previous studies have found that individuals sustaining injuries were almost universally given opioids and that repeat exposures over multiple healthcare encounters was very common.4,5 Such prescribing behavior was not confined to surgical interventions, or restricted to individuals injured in combat.4,5 These realities, combined with the psychological and emotional stressors on servicewomen and civilian dependents could have created a perfect storm increasing the potential for both sustained prescription opioid use and SUD. To the best of our knowledge, however, the associations between operational intensity and deployment stress and sustained opioid use and SUD, have not been longitudinally evaluated in a comprehensive manner.

Prior investigations heralding the high rate of opioid exposure among combat-injured veterans were conducted in cohorts that were 99% male.4 It is unclear that their findings apply to servicewomen. For servicewomen, the operational environment and deployment setting potentially increase both proximal and distal minority stressors, while simultaneously disrupting established social support networks.6 The deployed environment also increases the risk of exposure to military sexual trauma in addition to the potential for combat-related injury.6,7 Aside from the potential for combat-related trauma, the other associated stressors, disrupted support networks and the possibility of increased risk-taking behavior may also impact civilian dependents. These challenges may combine to further exacerbate the potential for sustained prescription opioid use and substance use disorder. For example, Cichowski et al. reported that women veterans with a history of military sexual trauma exhibited significantly greater odds of chronic opioid use for pelvic pain.7 Similarly, Beckman et al. documented a history of military sexual assault as a risk factor for post-traumatic stress and depression severity, as well as drug abuse including non-prescribed opioids.6

In this context, we used claims data from the military health system (MHS)3,5,8, 9, 10, 11 to conduct a natural experiment investigating the temporal associations between operational intensity and exposure to combat deployments on sustained prescription opioid use and SUD in servicewomen and civilian women dependents. We aimed to determine the extent to which the period of heightened operational intensity (2006–2013) was associated with an increased risk of sustained prescription opioid use and SUD among both servicewomen and dependents. We hypothesized, based on prior studies,3 that servicewomen and women civilian dependents in the time period 2006–2013 would exhibit higher likelihoods of sustained prescription opioid use and SUD when compared to comparands in the time period 2014–2022, a timeframe associated with lower operational intensity and fewer combat deployments.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We used claims-based data from the MHS Data Repository (fiscal years 2006–2022). The mechanisms through which this information is collected, accessed, and made available to researchers has been outlined in previously published work.9, 10, 11 Clinical care within the MHS is administered through facilities maintained by the Department of Defense (direct care) or civilian hospitals (private sector care).11 Diagnoses rendered over the course of care, and prescriptions that are issued, are captured by the central repository of the MHS irrespective of the site of service. The MHS is not responsible for care within Veterans Administration (VA) facilities and patients receiving treatment through the VA are not represented in our patient population. We adhered to published methods of MHS data retrieval, including accessing all clinical events for eligible patients within direct care or the private sector.5,9, 10, 11

We included adult women, ages 18–64, who were either women serving in the Army, Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps, or civilian women dependents of active duty servicemembers. Women were identified using demographic records within the MHS identification system based on beneficiary self-report and considered as representing ‘biologic sex.’ Each cohort was divided based on time period; 2006–2013 and 2014–2022, with the former time window representing a period of increased operational intensity and heightened number of deployments.1,3,4 These four categories were mutually exclusive and collectively exhaustive.

Within the timeframe of the dataset, claims for eligible servicewomen and dependents were queried for billed class II or class III opioid prescriptions (beginning with the initial prescription and ending at discharge or December 31, 2022).5,10,11 Based on previous work, we defined sustained prescription opioid use as six-months or longer of continuous prescription opioid use, without an interruption exceeding seven days.5,12 Individuals who demonstrated sustained prescription opioid use at any point during the surveillance period were categorized in the sustained opioid use group.

Sociodemographic and additional medical information were obtained from the MDR, including age, race (obtained via self-report as standard collection with enlistment and categorized as Asian or Pacific Islander, Black, White, Other), census region (Midwest, Northeast, South, West), sponsor rank (junior enlisted [EJ], senior enlisted [ES], officer [OF]), Charlson Comorbidity Index (categorized as 0 or one or more co-morbid conditions), and the presence of one or more of the following mental health diagnoses: depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress.3,9 Based on previous research, sponsor rank was used as a proxy for socioeconomic status, with junior enlisted sponsor rank considered to be representative of lower socioeconomic strata.9,10,13 Hispanic ethnicity was not available in our dataset. In secondary analysis, individuals diagnosed with substance use disorder (SUD) were identified using relevant International Classification of Diseases, Ninth (ICD-9) and Tenth Revision (ICD-10) codes.

Sustained prescription opioid use represented the primary outcome, while the primary exposure consisted of the combination of active-duty status (servicewomen or civilian dependent) and time of service (2006–2013 or 2014–2022). All comparisons were made to dependents in 2014–2022 as the referent. All other abstracted variables were considered confounders based on causal models informed by prior literature and clinical observations regarding the factors associated with the risks of developing sustained prescription opioid use and SUD.3, 4, 5,7,9,10,12 Due to the nature by which such data is collected and presented in the MHS, we included all covariates in our regression models for the purposes of adjustment. Missing data was minimal in all categories except for patient race where it was missing for 64% of cases and over 85% of dependents. We addressed this using multiple imputation under the missing at random assumption.

We report continuous data using means and standard deviations, and categorical data using frequencies and percentages. We employed multivariable log-binomial regression to adjust for confounding. All results were expressed using risk ratios (RR) with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI). We considered two-sided P-values <0.05, and RR with 95% CI exclusive of 1.0 statistically significant. All analyses were performed using SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute). Data were analyzed from April 2024 to April 2025.

This work was found exempt by the Institutional Review Board of the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences and Partners Institutional Review Board. The conduct and reporting of the research are aligned with the STROBE guidelines.

sec.title: Role of the funding source
sec.p: This study was funded through a grant from the U.S. Department of Defense, Defense Health Agency (award # HU00012320021). The funder had no role in the development, conduct, or determinations of the study, preparation of the manuscript, or decision to publish.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Sustained prescription opioid use was identified in 120,137 individuals (2.5%). Following adjusted analysis, when compared to dependents in 2014–2022, servicewomen from 2006 to 2013 demonstrated an increased risk of sustained prescription opioid use (RR 1.49, 95% CI 1.46–1.53). In 2014–2022, servicewomen had a lower risk of sustained opioid use compared to dependents (RR 0.47, 95% CI 0.45–0.49). Dependents in 2006–2013 were also found to have higher risk of sustained opioid use (RR 1.58, 95% CI 1.56–1.60; Table 2).Table 2

SUD was diagnosed in 418,079 (8.2%) of the study cohort. Servicewomen in the period 2006–2013 were at significantly greater risk of developing SUD (RR 1.07, 95% CI 1.06–1.08). During 2014–2022, servicewomen displayed a lower risk of SUD when compared to dependents (RR 0.80, 95% CI 0.79–0.81; Table 3). In contrast, dependents in 2006–2013 were at a higher risk of developing SUD (RR 1.24, 95% CI 1.24–1.25).Table 3

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study represents the first of its kind to longitudinally examine the development of sustained prescription opioid use and SUD among a large cohort of US women. We believe our findings highlight the deleterious impact of operational intensity and combat deployments on sustained prescription opioid use and SUD in both servicewomen and women civilian dependents. Starting insidiously in the early 2000s, the opioid crisis began to be recognized within the US health system over the time period of our study through a marked increase in the incidence of sustained prescription opioid use, substance use disorder, drug-related infections, transition to illegal opioids, and concomitant elevations in incarceration, opioid addiction treatment, and opioid-related deaths.14 At the same time, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan were contributing to heightened deployment schedules and repeated exposures to the combat environment that exerted psychological and physical stress on both servicemembers and their civilian dependents.1, 2, 3, 4

Previous research reported that both active-duty servicewomen and women civilian dependents associated with service in 2006–2013 were more likely to develop chronic pain conditions than comparands associated with later periods of service.3 This was attributed to several important factors including the rigors of exposure to the combat environment, repeated deployments, emotional distress impacting both servicemembers and their dependents, and exposure to military sexual trauma. These same issues are also known to influence the proclivity of sustained prescription opioid use and SUD that were encountered in the present investigation. While both of these conditions are multifactorial, we believe that the various psychological and physical stressors associated with increased operational intensity and repeated deployments leave civilians and servicemembers alike susceptible to sustained opioid use and SUD.2

Agniel et al. previously characterized opioid exposure as a household risk.15 In their cohort study, the hazard for opioid misuse among family members of a chronic opioid user were increased by more than a factor of 2.5. In that investigation, the index patient in households with opioid prescriptions and opioid prescription refills were both more likely to be female (51.4% and 52.6%, respectively).15 Similarly, in a large cohort of Medicare beneficiaries undergoing total knee replacement, women were over-represented among intermittent and continuous opioid users, when compared to those who were opioid non-users at the time of surgery.16 In this study, women represented over 76% of the population who were continuous opioid users. Prior research on combat-related injuries maintained there was no significant differences between males and females with respect to sustained prescription opioid use.4 Initial treatment following the traumatic event could play a vital role in creating a predilection for sustained use. For example, research has shown that both too little and too much opioid use can increase the risk of long-term dependence and pain disorders, highlighting the need for pain management approaches that carefully balance pain relief against the potential for sustained opioid use.17

Prominent drivers of chronic opioid use and misuse in women include sexual trauma, familial and social problems.18 The potential for such issues to be present is particularly elevated in the high-stress environment of heightened operational intensity and combat-related deployments. Moreover, people exposed to trauma may be more likely to use opioids long-term and transition to a substance use disorder, possibly as a way to manage both physical and psychological pain.6,19 Rabenhorst et al. previously reported that rates of moderate to severe spousal abuse and alcohol related spousal abuse were elevated in Air Force personnel following deployment.20 Furthermore, an injured spouse exposed to opioids for combat-related trauma and who then progresses to chronic opioid use themselves would additionally increase the risk among civilian dependents, as was attested in the study of Agniel et al.15 Finally, Davis et al. indicated that women exhibited greater functional opioid-related impairment as compared to men and progressed to a diagnosable disorder faster,18 a reality that may be reflected in the higher risk ratios of SUD and susustained opioid use that were observed among the civilian women dependents in our analysis.

There are several factors that provide face validity for our results and support their translational capacity. The other factors associated with sustained opioid use and SUD in this study have also been recognized in other research settings, including age, socioeconomic status, medical comorbidities, and mental health conditions.9,15,16,18 The risk ratios of the time-periods associated with sustained opioid use and SUD all indicate clinically important alterations. The observed reductions in sustained prescription opioid use and SUD in the cohorts associated with military service in 2014–2022 are also aligned with previous literature suggesting meaningful reductions in sustained opioid dependence that resulted from the implementation of Federal regulations and pain management guidelines beginning in 2017.21, 22, 23 Furthermore, increased awareness and a shift away from opioid-based pain regimens to multimodal analgesia contributed to the reduced proclivity for sustained opioid use and SUD in the 2014–2022 window.24,25 While the end of the 2014–2022 window included the time period of the COVID-19 pandemic, the impact of the pandemic on sustained opioid use was not uniform and highly dependent on the clinical context. Currie et al. reported that the ordering of opioid medications was only impacted in the early phases of the pandemic and then rebounded to pre-pandemic levels.26 Crawford et al. documented increased rates of sustained opioid use in all phases of the pandemic, when compared to the time period immediately preceding the onset of COVID-19.27 We are unaware of studies that show a persistent signal of reduction in sustained prescription opioid use that is attributable to the impact of COVID-19 on healthcare delivery and prescribing practices. Due to the previously demonstrated representative nature of the population served by the MHS under age 65,3,5,9,11 we believe that our findings could be generalizable to a broader demographic.

As a result, the findings of this investigation are important to the US healthcare system, policy makers and the Department of Defense. Foremost, at a macroscopic level, our study is the first we are aware of to objectively demonstrate the deleterious impact of heightened deployment schedules, operational intensity, combat exposure and associated familial stressors on sustained prescription opioid use and SUD in uniformed servicemembers and civilian dependents who are women. This is of paramount importance as US women are now serving in direct combat roles in the military and the combat intensity and lethality of warfare in the future is only anticipated to increase.28 The translational nature of this population means that we believe these realities are also likely to be present to a certain extent in civilian women who are exposed to similar familial, occupational, or environmental stressors even in the absence of direct military affiliation. Such situations could include law enforcement, presence at mass casualty events, and front-line medical and behavioral health providers, especially those serving over the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.29 At a minimum, clinicians in the Veterans Administration system and civilian sector should be aware of the apparent heightened risk of sustained prescription opioid use and SUD for women veterans who served in Iraq and/or Afghanistan over the time period 2006–2013, as well as an elevated risk of SUD and sustained opioid use among women spouses and children of individuals with similar service history. We wish to emphasize, however, that our findings should not be interpreted to mean that people who experience combat or trauma should be denied opioids when clinically appropriate. Instead, our results simply emphasize the need for thoughtful pain management strategies capable of addressing physical and psychological health needs while also reducing the prospect of long-term opioid use.

Limitations to this study include a reliance on claims-based data and coding, without clinical granularity. We are, therefore, unable to understand the exact circumstances or diagnostic criteria that were used when rendering a diagnosis of SUD. The nature of the data imparted by the MHS also means that we are largely restricted to administrative level patient information and there is prospect for residual confounding including a lack of information around prescription intensity. Although prescription opioid information is widely used in studies such as ours as a proxy for use, we recognize that the use of these medications do not always align with the receipt of prescriptions including prospects for misuse, abuse and illegal consumption. The data is also subject to secular trends in the acceptance of, and social support for, seeking help with behavioral health conditions and logistic realities around documentation of substance use disorder. In line with this, over the time period of our investigation, the Department of Defense improved access to care for SUD for servicemembers and dependents. The actual prevalence of behavioral health disorders and substance use disorder may be underrepresented within our population as a result. While our cohort did exhibit restricted clinical variation with respect to comorbid medical conditions, we believe this is reflective of the general population in the age range 26–34 and therefore is not a threat to our contentions regarding translational capacity. Nonetheless, the findings may not be entirely applicable to older populations or those with more extensive medical or behavioral health issues at baseline. Due to issues around restricted reporting on race, particularly among dependents, we used multiple imputation to facilitate our analyses. Furthermore, ethnicity was not available in our dataset, and thus we cannot comment on the impact of cultural differences and concomitant structural drivers on sustained opioid use and SUD. As historically, and even in the time period under investigation, men represented a very small minority of civilian dependents,8 we used civilian dependent women in the time period 2014–2022 as the control group in this investigation. While the timeframe 2006–2013 is broadly accepted as a period of increased operational intensity, we acknowledge this is a proxy and we do not have specific information about the operational environment or deployment locations. Moreover, we are unable to characterize the indications for opioid prescriptions or account for misuse or illicit use.

In conclusion, we found that sustained prescription opioid use was significantly increased among servicewomen and women dependents during a period of heightened operational intensity (2006–2013), and servicewoman and women civilian dependents from this period also carried an increased likelihood of developing SUD. We believe that our findings are translatable to the civilian sector, given that the covered population of the MHS has previously been shown to be analogous to the US demographic aged 18–64. In particular, clinicians in the Veterans Administration system and civilian sector should be aware of a heightened risk of sustained prescription opioid use for women veterans who served in Iraq and/or Afghanistan over the time period 2006–2013, as well as an elevated risk of SUD and sustained opioid use among women spouses and children of individuals with such service history.

sec.title: Contributors
sec.p: AJS, KEH, MRB, MOH, MW, and TPK had full access to all the data in the study and take responsibility for the integrity of the data and the accuracy of the data analysis.

sec.title: Data sharing statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the Defense Health Agency, but restrictions may apply to the availability of these data, which were used under a data sharing agreement for the current study, and so are not publicly available. Data are however available from the authors upon reasonable request and with permission of the Defense Health Agency.

sec.title: Disclaimer
sec.p: The contents of this publication are the sole responsibility of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the views, assertions, opinions, or policies of the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences (USUHS) or the Departments of the Army, Navy, or Air Force. Mention of trade names, commercial products, or organizations does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
